persons.name: Alexander vonHumboldt
persons.description: German geographer, naturalist and explorer. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: JamesCooke
persons.description: Cooke or Cook. Anglican minister of Ardwick (near Manchester). Author of Drill Husbandry Perfected.

places.name: Cambridge
places.description: Cambridge is the county town of Cambridgeshire.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
works.author: William Watson

persons.name: JosephBanks
persons.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

persons.name: Thomas AndrewKnight
persons.description: Knight was a botanist and horticulturalist. He was the second president of the Royal Horticulture Society. Davy frequently fished on Knight's esates in the Welsh Marches. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnWalker
persons.description: Professor of Natural History at Edinburgh University. Served as Moderator of the Church of Scotland during 1790.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London

persons.name: CharlesBonnet
persons.description: Genevan lawyer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: StephenHales
persons.description: English clergyman who made major contributions to a range of scientific fields including botany, pneumatic chemistry and physiology.  FRSL.

persons.name: Thomas AndrewKnight

persons.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
persons.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Thomas CharlesHope
persons.description: Professor of Medicine and Chemistry at Edinburgh University. Discovered the element strontium and seems to have played a role in Davy's appointment to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: Thomas AndrewKnight
persons.description: Knight was a botanist and horticulturalist. He was the second president of the Royal Horticulture Society. Davy frequently fished on Knight's esates in the Welsh Marches. FRSL.

persons.name: John BakerHolroyd
persons.description: Independent-minded MP; from 1802 1st Baron Sheffield and from 1816 1st Earl of Sheffield. President of the Board of Agriculture, 1802-1806. During autumn 1803 Davy stayed with him for three weeks at his Sussex seat, Sheffield Place. FRSL.

persons.name: Henri-LouisDuhamel du Monceau
persons.description: French physician, naval engineer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

persons.description: Genevan lawyer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: CarlLinnaeus
persons.description: Professor of Physic and Botany at Uppsala University. Developed the modern system of taxonomic classification. ForMemFRSL.

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

persons.name: RichardPennant
persons.description: From 1783 1st Baron Penrhyn, owner of Penrhyn estate, on the outskirts of Bangor, North Wales. MP, slave-owner and staunch pro-slavery advocate.

places.name: Cheshire
places.description: A county in north-western England. The county town is Chester.
